articles.headline: Trump Associate Boasted That Moscow Business Deal ‘Will Get Donald Elected’
articles.snippet: Emails show that Felix Sater promised to get Vladimir Putin’s support for a Trump Tower in Moscow. “Our boy can become president,” he wrote.
articles.abstract: Emails show that Felix Sater promised to get Vladimir Putin’s support for a Trump Tower in Moscow. “Our boy can become president,” he wrote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A business associate of President Trump promised in 2015 to engineer a real estate deal with the aid of the president of Russia, Vladimir V. Putin, that he said would help Mr. Trump win the presidency.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Uber’s C.E.O. Pick, Dara Khosrowshahi, Steps Into Brighter Spotlight
articles.snippet: Mr. Khosrowshahi has many tasks ahead of him, including repairing Uber’s internal culture and preparing the company for a self-driving future.
articles.abstract: Mr. Khosrowshahi has many tasks ahead of him, including repairing Uber’s internal culture and preparing the company for a self-driving future.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Dara Khosrowshahi’s family immigrated to the United States from Iran in 1978, when their country was convulsed by revolution. They were not particularly welcomed in America, and were broke.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Nellie Bowles

articles.headline: Day Trading in Wall Street’s Complex ‘Fear Gauge’ Proliferates
articles.snippet: This explosion in interest is prompting concerns that investors may not be truly aware of what they are getting into.
articles.abstract: This explosion in interest is prompting concerns that investors may not be truly aware of what they are getting into.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each morning, at the market’s open, Seth M. Golden, a former logistics manager at a Target store, fires up the computer in his home office in northern Florida and does what he has done for years: Put on bets that Wall Street’s index of volatility, the VIX, will keep falling.

articles.headline: Uber’s C.E.O. Choice Faces a Question of Ambitions
articles.snippet: Under its co-founder Travis Kalanick, Uber set out to revolutionize modern transportation. Its new C.E.O. may have a smaller, less risky vision.
articles.abstract: Under its co-founder Travis Kalanick, Uber set out to revolutionize modern transportation. Its new C.E.O. may have a smaller, less risky vision.
articles.lead_paragraph: In private and sometimes in public, Travis Kalanick was fond of describing Uber, the car-hailing service he co-founded and commanded absolutely, as the Amazon of the transportation business.

articles.headline: North Korea Fires Missile Over Japan
articles.snippet: Pyongyang carried out one of its most provocative missile tests in recent years, prompting Japan to issue an alert for residents to take cover.
articles.abstract: Pyongyang carried out one of its most provocative missile tests in recent years, prompting Japan to issue an alert for residents to take cover.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea carried out one of its most provocative missile tests in recent years early Tuesday morning, hurling a ballistic missile directly over Japan that prompted the government in Tokyo to warn residents in its path to take cover.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Coffee and Cots as Houston Houses Thousands in a Convention Center
articles.snippet: The George R. Brown Convention Center, in downtown Houston, is a hub of the enormous relief operation as the city confronts catastrophic flooding.
articles.abstract: The George R. Brown Convention Center, in downtown Houston, is a hub of the enormous relief operation as the city confronts catastrophic flooding.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The rescued are almost always wet when they arrive — slick, shuffling and staggering after hours in the rain. They are met with blankets and a security check, dry clothes and green cots. And then there is a feeling of relief that, for the moment, they have left the floodwaters behind.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Apple’s Tim Cook Barnstorms for ‘Moral Responsibility’
articles.snippet: Don’t expect him to become a politician, but the Apple C.E.O. sees gaps in governmental social policies that he believes companies like his are obliged to help fill.
articles.abstract: Don’t expect him to become a politician, but the Apple C.E.O. sees gaps in governmental social policies that he believes companies like his are obliged to help fill.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — “The reality is that government, for a long period of time, has for whatever set of reasons become less functional and isn’t working at the speed that it once was. And so it does fall, I think, not just on business but on all other areas of society to step up.”

articles.headline: Deluged Texas Braces for More Rain, and Years of Recovery
articles.snippet: The flooding from Tropical Storm Harvey that has turned neighborhoods into lakes is just the start of a disaster that will take years to overcome.
articles.abstract: The flooding from Tropical Storm Harvey that has turned neighborhoods into lakes is just the start of a disaster that will take years to overcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As one of the most destructive storms in the nation’s history pummeled southeast Texas for a fourth day, forecasts on Tuesday morning called for still more rain, making clear that catastrophic flooding that had turned neighborhoods into lakes was just the start of a disaster that would take years to overcome.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Richard Pérez-Peña and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Home Health Care: Shouldn’t It Be Work Worth Doing?
articles.snippet: Watching over older people is among the fastest-growing occupations. With more training and flexibility, it could help support a future middle class.
articles.abstract: Watching over older people is among the fastest-growing occupations. With more training and flexibility, it could help support a future middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: Do you know who is going to care for you when you are old and frail? By current standards, it’s likely to be a middle-aged immigrant woman, with maybe a high school education and little if any training, making $20,000 a year.

articles.headline: A Pacifist Japan Starts to Embrace the Military
articles.snippet: As the North Korean missile threat grows, there are signs that Japan’s citizens are moving away from the country’s postwar pacifism.
articles.abstract: As the North Korean missile threat grows, there are signs that Japan’s citizens are moving away from the country’s postwar pacifism.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOTEMBA, Japan — The Japanese soldiers jumped out of the jeeps, unloaded the antitank missiles and dropped to the ground. Within minutes, they aimed and fired, striking hypothetical targets nearly a half-mile away.
